title: 103_s170
content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS. The Congress recognizes John Birks "Dizzy" Gillespie as a renowned jazz artist, honored for his musicianship and ability to connect with audiences. Gillespie's contributions to jazz as a musician, composer, and cultural ambassador have solidified his legacy as an iconic figure in American music history. He has received prestigious awards such as the Kennedy Center Honors and the Smithsonian Medal for his lifetime achievements in the performing arts. Dizzy Gillespie received numerous honors for his lifetime achievements as a musician, composer, and bandleader, including the National Medal of Arts, a Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award, and the Commandant D'Ordre des Arts et Lettres in France. He also performed for royalty and world leaders, including four American Presidents, and was crowned a traditional African chief in Nigeria. Dizzy Gillespie was acclaimed as a visionary risk taker who integrated ethnic influences into jazz, pioneering "be-bop" with Charlie Parker. He incorporated Afro-Cuban, Brazilian, and Caribbean music into jazz, transforming the genre and influencing 20th-century musical culture. Dizzy Gillespie's United Nations Orchestra showcased his universal musical philosophy in 20 countries across continents since 1988. He was the first jazz artist appointed as a Cultural Ambassador by the Department of State in 1956, touring successfully through various regions. In 1989, he represented the US on a groundbreaking month-long journey. In 1989, Dizzy Gillespie represented the United States on a groundbreaking month-long tour in Africa sponsored by the United States Information Agency Arts America Program. The President is authorized to present a gold medal to Mrs. Lorraine Gillespie in memory of her late husband, John Birks "Dizzy" Gillespie, for his musical genius. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike the medal with suitable emblems. An amount not exceeding $25,000 is authorized for this purpose. The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to strike and sell duplicates of the gold medal in bronze under regulations to cover costs. The proceeds will reimburse the appropriation used. The medals struck are considered national medals under United States Code.
